an6.36:1.1: “Mendicants, there are these six roots of arguments.
an6.36:1.3: Firstly, a mendicant is irritable and hostile.
an6.36:1.4: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
an6.36:1.5: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an6.36:1.6: If you see such a root of arguments in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.
an6.36:1.7: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:1.8: That’s how to give up this bad root of arguments, so it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:2.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is offensive and contemptuous …
an6.36:2.4: with wicked desires and wrong view …
an6.36:2.5: They’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
an6.36:2.6: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the Teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
an6.36:2.7: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
an6.36:2.8: If you see such a root of arguments in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.
an6.36:2.9: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:2.10: That’s how to give up this bad root of arguments, so it doesn’t come up in the future.
an6.36:2.11: These are the six roots of arguments.”
